text: Patient: That, that’s, okay. Doctor: Uh, the, uh, the idea of those drugs. It depends on which of the drugs. There’s a bunch of different HIV drugs. I can’t remember which one you mentioned. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of those drugs block the DNA in certain ways, but in the virus, mostly. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of them block enzymes that the virus makes. And I think those things may also block cancer enzymes, is what they- Patient: Is what the trick is? Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Uh, anyway, I’ll, I’ll- Patient: Yeah. If you get a chance. Doctor: Will think about that. Okay. Patient: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay. So I will try to get a hold of you Friday.

text: Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I, I don’t know enough about either drug in terms of the side effect profile. I, I know the one where you get one or the other has been pretty well tolerated. Uh, and the other drug is, uh, I haven’t put anybody on the trial yet, so I don’t have the experience, but, uh, I know from our meetings, I haven’t heard any signal that says this is horribly toxic. So, uh, so I, I think side effect wise, I don’t think that we’re going to have that much problem. It’s really just a matter of can we-? Family Member: So they saw a lot of more spots on his bone from the last, uh-? Doctor: Yeah. Let me, uh, pull that up. So- (pause14sec) Patient: Um hum. (Laughter) Doctor: Uh, right. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: It’s too bad they haven’t came up with something more with the bones whereas they can, you know? Doctor: Well. text: Family Member: No. Patient: Oh about two thousand twelve. No, I didn’t even have it then. It wasn’t even bad as this. No that’s why Dr. G took it under advisement. Doctor: And has it gotten worse? Patient: Oh yeah, yeah, it’s gotten worse. I’m trying to think what; I had a CAT scan that’s what it was of both my lungs last week. Doctor: What did they tell you about that? Patient: They didn’t tell me anything about it yet. I see Dr. G___ next week. Doctor: And you’re still taking the Enzalutamide? Patient: What’s that? Doctor: The Xtandi. Patient: Yes, I am, yes. Four pills a day. Doctor: Anything else you want to tell me about how you feel? Patient: I feel pretty good.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And your PSA will also be lower. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because part of the PSA going up with the testosterone was just turning on the production number. Patient: Of the testosterone? Doctor: Even if it didn’t make the cancer grow, or, or the cancer grew, whatever, just turning off the, the hormone might turn off the production. So, um, usually I see the PSA drop back down some. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So lots of things to throw at you. So what I’m going- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: My work is going to be to figure out what it would cost us to get on the Xtandi. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then this biopsy part of the trials, what, what’s required. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Uh, you know, I’ve been having, you know, just like something happening, and- Doctor: But it’s not effective enough that you can have sex with it? Is that what you’re saying? Doctor: Okay. So you want to get better? Patient: Yes. So I just want to be patient. Doctor: Okay, and it may, and it very well may, because it’s just, uh, let’s see, it was done, you had the operation on-. Patient: Uh, on the fourteenth of September. Doctor: September? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So you’re not quite a year?

text: Patient: Oh that’s fine, music Doctor: …music, I know. Patient: My son’s a music teacher so. Doctor: Oh there you go. text: Patient: I’ve got several questions for ya now. If I get the drug, what are the most common side effects? Doctor: I would say, fatigue. Patient: Fatigue? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. It’s kind of, it’s a little bit of a weird fatigue. You know? Like sometimes your brain’s okay, but your body doesn’t want to get off the couch. So you can’t really yell at him that much if that happens. But if it’s too much on the couch, then we’re going to have to, you know, reduce the number of pills. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, yeah. Patient: And if I am on the drug- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: How soon would I feel any? Doctor: Probably about three weeks. Patient: About three weeks? Doctor: Um hum. Yeah. Patient: So I should be good for three weeks anyway?

text: Family Member: Spine, ribs, and shoulder? (pause11sec) Doctor: Yeah. The one, the one thing we see also with, we’ve seen with the testosterone, is something called a flair. Meaning spots are there- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - but we don’t see them very well, and then we give a drug like that, they can get more intense so they show up. And I think these are spots that are, you know, been there for probably a year or two just below the radar. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It’s just a matter of, you know, we’re seeing them now. Uh, and whether the testosterone helped to see them better, that’s what we see with some other guys. So, uh, but I think certainly there’s enough there that we’ve got to keep- Family Member: Do something else? Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Alright. Doctor: So I will call you probably Friday- Patient: Okay. Doctor: With some information. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: We do, speaking of trials, we do have a trial coming up. It’s not open yet. But it’s probably going to be a trial after, uh, uh, actually, let me, let me take a step back. The other trial I didn’t tell you. We do have one other trial, uh, that involves, uh, a combination of two things. Uh, one is called, radium. And radium is a radioactive element that looks like calcium. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And the idea is we can trick the cancer, because prostate cancer is making, stimulating the bone to make new bone. (Sound Door opens) Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So we give this radium that looks like calcium, so he gets put in there also, and can give radiation kind of focally. So where there’s spots on the bone, it gives radiation, but it doesn’t radiate the liver or the lung. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So that drug, uh, would be another possible option, because it’s a, it’s an approved drug. I tend to use it in men who have more pain. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Have, you know, multiple bone spots. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, right now, we’re doing a trial where we’re giving that drug in combination with a vaccine. The vaccine is called, sipuleucel-T. And that’s the only vaccine we have for any cancer. Both drugs together have shown that they can improve, uh, how long men live with, from prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
